Description: Shoulder sherd of black-figured pottery krater; interior: reserved at top, glazed below; exterior: at top of shoulder, tongue frieze; below, black-figure decoration consisting possibly of Athena (helmeted head with added white for flesh on face remaining) to right; at right, perhaps part of her spear.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Mayence and Verhoogen identify the sherd as coming from a Clazomenian krater; some details rather suggest a Late Corinthian red-ground piece, but the clay is not Corinthian.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 21, pl. 28, no. 13)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.2140) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
